section.name: Import database with WEB-service.
section.p: If you decided to move from lite standalone (single user) SQlite version of Beige-Accounting into high load enterprise-ready database MySql, then use WEB-service Import database

Bob decided to checks out this. He installed Apache Tomcat and MySql according https://github.com/demidenko05/beigesoft-accounting-weboio README.txt. He download file beigesoft-accounting-weboio.war from central Maven repository https://search.maven.org/#search%7Cga%7C1%7Cg%3A%22org.beigesoft%22 and put it into webapps folder of Apache Tomcat. He launched SQlite version Beige Accounting on 8081 port. Source local database:
Then he started Tomcat and opened address http://localhost:8080/beigesoft-accounting-weboio/ Destination database (cloud version):
He entered "URL of WEB-service of another database:" as "http://localhost:8081/secure/sendEntities" and leaved user/password fields empty then pressed "submit":

For real cloud WEB-application http://localhost:8081 is not available, so you have two choices:
Make MySql copy in local computer, then restore backup on remote cloud database with MySql backup software
Make SQlite version internet accessible - non-localhost i.e. public it on cloud (it MUST be only HTTPS(encrypted) accessible), but at first you MUST switch on JDBC (or other) authentication in SQLite version and add users with strong passwords, see https://github.com/demidenko05/beigesoft-webcrud that uses SQlite and JDBC authentication for Apache Tomcat standard.
